<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A novel coordination polymer [La(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) has been prepared by hydrothermal reaction of 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>) with La(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, which exhibits an unusual three-dimensional (3D) (6,6)-connected <ce:bold>nia</ce:bold> net with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">9</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>). Meanwhile, a two-dimensional (2D) (3,6)-connected (3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4)(3<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.7) coordination network {[Ho<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>S1</ce:bold>) was also obtained with partially deprotonated H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">2–</ce:sup> ligand. Comparison of the structural differences between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold> suggests that the different metal sources play an important role in the construction of such coordination networks.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel coordination polymer [La(L)(H2O)]n (1) has been prepared by hydrothermal reaction of 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (H3 L) with La(NO3)3⋅6H2O, which exhibits an unusual three-dimensional (3D) (6,6)-connected nia net with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (412.63)(49.66). Meanwhile, a two-dimensional (2D) (3,6)-connected (32.4)(34.43.52.65.7) coordination network {[Ho2(HL)3(H2O)2]⋅H2O}n (S1) was also obtained with partially deprotonated HL 2- ligand. Comparison of the structural differences between 1 and S1 suggests that the different metal sources play an important role in the construction of such coordination networks.

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two coordination polymers, [La(L)(H2O)]n (1) and {[Ho2(HL)3(H2O)2]⋅H2O}n (S1) (H3 L =5-hydroxyisophthalic acid), have been prepared. Complex 1 exhibits the nia topological net with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (412.63)(49.66), whereas complex S1 has a 2D (3,6)-connected (32.4)(34.43.52.65.7) topology. Remarkably, complex 1 is the first lanthanide network with the hydroxyl group of 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid coordinating to the metal atoms.

elements.clean_text:
Highlights

► A unique 3D LaIII nia network with (412.63)(49.66) topology. ► Structure modulation driven by different metal sources. ► The hydroxyl group of 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid coordinating with LaIII 

The construction of coordination polymers based on assembly of metal atoms and multifunctional organic ligands has been extensively studied in recent years owing to their intriguing topologies and potential applications as functional materials . In comparison with the d-block transition metal (TM) ions, lanthanide atoms have higher coordination numbers and more flexible coordination spheres, which make it even more difficult to control the structures. In addition, according to the hard-soft acid-base theory, the lanthanide atoms have high affinity for oxygen donor atoms . In general, multicarboxylate ligands are usually employed in the construction of lanthanide polymeric complexes . Among them, 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (H3 L), as a carboxylate derivative, has attracted much interest based on the following considerations: (1) it has two carboxyl groups which may exhibit diverse coordination modes; (2) the hydroxyl group may provide the additional binding site and connect metal atoms to generate more complicated structures incorporation with the carboxyl groups; and (3) the carboxyl and hydroxyl groups are good candidates for hydrogen bonds to construct supramolecular structures with higher dimensionality. Thus far, several lanthanide coordination polymers constructed by using H3 L have been reported . For example, Li and co-workers have hydrothermally synthesized a series of 2D lanthanide layered structures, {[Ln(HL)(H2O)5]⋅0.5HL⋅H2O}n (Ln=Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, and Er), which exhibited the helical cation chains with organic ligands as templates . Also, Yan, et al.  and Huang, et al.  have successfully obtained a series of another 2D lanthanide networks, namely {[Ln(HL)(H2 L)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O}n.(Ln=La, Tb, Er, Sm for Yan, et al. and Nd for Huang, et al.), which comprise 1D Ln-O-C-O-Ln chains. By the reaction of La(ClO4)3⋅6H2O with H3 L in the presence of NaOH and K2C2O4⋅6H2O, Si, et al. isolated a complicated 3D structure with coordinated oxalic ions, {[La2(ox)(HL)2(H2O)4]⋅2H2O}n (ox=oxalate) . Thus, further efforts are required to provide more information on the coordination behavior of H3 L, in order to design and prepare new crystalline materials with such types of organic ligands.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In this work, a 3D (6,6)-connected <ce:bold>nia</ce:bold> lanthanide network [La(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was obtained by the reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> with La(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O under hydrothermal condition. Moreover, a 2D (3,6)-connected (3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4)(3<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.7) coordination polymer {[Ho<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>S1</ce:bold>) was synthesized in this research by changing the metal source. Herein, we report the syntheses, crystal/topological structures, and properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this work, a 3D (6,6)-connected nia lanthanide network [La(L)(H2O)]n (1) was obtained by the reaction of H3 L with La(NO3)3⋅6H2O under hydrothermal condition. Moreover, a 2D (3,6)-connected (32.4)(34.43.52.65.7) coordination polymer {[Ho2(HL)3(H2O)2]⋅H2O}n (S1) was synthesized in this research by changing the metal source. Herein, we report the syntheses, crystal/topological structures, and properties of 1 and S1.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold> were obtained by the hydrothermal reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> with Ln(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>La for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and Ho for <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold>) in the presence of NaOH . The compositions were confirmed by elementary analysis and IR spectra, and the phase purities of the bulk samples for luminescent/thermal measurements were identified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (please see Fig. S6 in the Supplementary material).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complexes 1 and S1 were obtained by the hydrothermal reaction of H3 L with Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O (Ln=La for 1 and Ho for S1) in the presence of NaOH . The compositions were confirmed by elementary analysis and IR spectra, and the phase purities of the bulk samples for luminescent/thermal measurements were identified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (please see Fig. S6 in the Supplementary material).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a very complicated 3D coordination framework . The asymmetric unit consists of one La(III) atom, one <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">3–</ce:sup> ligand, and one coordinated water molecule. Each La(III) atom is nine-coordinated and shows a distorted tricapped trigonal prism coordination geometry (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>) finished by eight carboxylate O atoms (O1, O2, O2A, O5B, O4C, O3D, O4D, and O5E) from six distinct <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">3–</ce:sup> ligands and one O<ce:inf loc="post">water</ce:inf> atom (here O6). The La−O bond distances and the bond angles around each La(III) atom are in the ranges from 2.458(3) to 2.754(3) Å and 49.12(11) to 153.72(12)°, respectively (see Table S1 in the Supplementary material). In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the carboxylate and hydroxyl groups of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand are fully deprotonated. The <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">3–</ce:sup> ligand shows the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>-bridging mode (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>), which connect six La(III) atoms through one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-hydroxyl and two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> chelating/bridging carboxylate groups. Remarkably, the examples with the hydroxyl group involving in the metal coordination in different forms of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligands are still rare even though there are a few of coordination polymers constructed by H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligands . To the best of our knowledge, only four such polymeric complexes were reported, namely [Ni(H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> [C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2,2'-bis(1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-imidazolyl)ether] , {[CuZn(H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> [bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>4,4'-bipyridyl] , {18-crown·Cs[H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>]}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
 and {(Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)[PbSr(H<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)]}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
. Significantly, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits the first lanthanide example in which the hydroxyl group of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand takes part in the coordination with the metal atoms. Based on the linkage of carboxylater groups in <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">3–</ce:sup> ligands, La(III) atoms are connected to generate an infinite 2D layered motif (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Moreover, the connections of <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-hydroxyl groups in <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">3–</ce:sup> ligands bridge the 2D motifs mentioned above to lead to the formation of the final 3D network (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). In addition, in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the benzene π planes of <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">3–</ce:sup> ligands do not interact obviously with each other [the closest centroid–centroid separation is 5.223<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å checked and calculated by PLATON procedure, which is very longer than 3.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The structure of 1 has a very complicated 3D coordination framework . The asymmetric unit consists of one La(III) atom, one L 3- ligand, and one coordinated water molecule. Each La(III) atom is nine-coordinated and shows a distorted tricapped trigonal prism coordination geometry (see  ) finished by eight carboxylate O atoms (O1, O2, O2A, O5B, O4C, O3D, O4D, and O5E) from six distinct L 3- ligands and one Owater atom (here O6). The La-O bond distances and the bond angles around each La(III) atom are in the ranges from 2.458(3) to 2.754(3) Å and 49.12(11) to 153.72(12)°, respectively (see Table S1 in the Supplementary material). In 1, the carboxylate and hydroxyl groups of H3 L ligand are fully deprotonated. The L 3- ligand shows the μ 6-bridging mode (see  ), which connect six La(III) atoms through one μ 2-hydroxyl and two μ 2-η 1:η 2 chelating/bridging carboxylate groups. Remarkably, the examples with the hydroxyl group involving in the metal coordination in different forms of H3 L ligands are still rare even though there are a few of coordination polymers constructed by H3 L ligands . To the best of our knowledge, only four such polymeric complexes were reported, namely [Ni(HL)(C10H14N4O)(H2O)]n [C10H14N4O=2,2'-bis(1H-imidazolyl)ether] , {[CuZn(HL)2(bipy)(H2O)]⋅1.5H2O}n [bipy=4,4'-bipyridyl] , {18-crown⋅Cs[HL]}n  and {(Me2NH2)[PbSr(HL)(L)]}n . Significantly, complex 1 exhibits the first lanthanide example in which the hydroxyl group of H3 L ligand takes part in the coordination with the metal atoms. Based on the linkage of carboxylater groups in L 3- ligands, La(III) atoms are connected to generate an infinite 2D layered motif (see  ). Moreover, the connections of μ 2-hydroxyl groups in L 3- ligands bridge the 2D motifs mentioned above to lead to the formation of the final 3D network (see  ). In addition, in 1, the benzene π planes of L 3- ligands do not interact obviously with each other [the closest centroid-centroid separation is 5.223Å checked and calculated by PLATON procedure, which is very longer than 3.8Å].

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">From the viewpoint of topology, both <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>
<ce:sup loc="post">3–</ce:sup> ligand and La(III) atom can be regarded as isolated 6-connectors due to each of them linking six of the other ones. Thus, the overall net of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be reduced as a binodal (6,6)-connected network with the Point (Schläfli) symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">9</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) calculated by TOPOS program (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>) , which has been referred by O′Keeffe as an <ce:bold>nia</ce:bold> notation .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: From the viewpoint of topology, both L 3- ligand and La(III) atom can be regarded as isolated 6-connectors due to each of them linking six of the other ones. Thus, the overall net of 1 can be reduced as a binodal (6,6)-connected network with the Point (Schläfli) symbol of (49.66)(412.63) calculated by TOPOS program (see  ) , which has been referred by O'Keeffe as an nia notation .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">When we used Ho(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O instead of La(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in this research, a 2D (3,6)-connected (3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4)(3<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.7) topological net (<ce:bold>S1</ce:bold>) was obtained under the same condition (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor> as well as Figs. S1–S3; brief description and discussion of <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold> were shown in the Supplementary material). The results indicate that the more complicated structures can be obtained due to the increase of coordination number of metal atoms with highly connected ligands. Comparison of the structural differences between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold> suggests that the different metal sources play an important role in their structural assemblies.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: When we used Ho(NO3)3⋅6H2O instead of La(NO3)3⋅6H2O in this research, a 2D (3,6)-connected (32.4)(34.43.52.65.7) topological net (S1) was obtained under the same condition (see    as well as Figs. S1-S3; brief description and discussion of S1 were shown in the Supplementary material). The results indicate that the more complicated structures can be obtained due to the increase of coordination number of metal atoms with highly connected ligands. Comparison of the structural differences between 1 and S1 suggests that the different metal sources play an important role in their structural assemblies.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">In addition, the solid-state photoluminescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold> were investigated at room temperature, as shown in Fig. S4 in the Supplementary material. The luminescence emission bands with the peak maxima (λ<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf>) were observed at 371<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>341<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold>, respectively. To further analyze the nature of these emission bands, the photoluminescent properties of the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> have also been investigated under the same experimental conditions. The emission band for free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand is attributable to the π*<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>n transitions. The fluorescent behaviors of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold> are very similar to that observed for the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand (see Fig. S4 in the Supplementary material), which displays the maximal emission at 364<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation at 345<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Moreover, the emission mechanism for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold> can be properly ascribed to charge–transfer transition between the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand and the central Ln(III) ion .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In addition, the solid-state photoluminescent properties of 1 and S1 were investigated at room temperature, as shown in Fig. S4 in the Supplementary material. The luminescence emission bands with the peak maxima (λmax) were observed at 371nm (λex =341nm) for 1 and 350nm (λex =280nm) for S1, respectively. To further analyze the nature of these emission bands, the photoluminescent properties of the free H3 L have also been investigated under the same experimental conditions. The emission band for free H3 L ligand is attributable to the π*→n transitions. The fluorescent behaviors of 1 and S1 are very similar to that observed for the free H3 L ligand (see Fig. S4 in the Supplementary material), which displays the maximal emission at 364nm upon excitation at 345nm. Moreover, the emission mechanism for 1 and S1 can be properly ascribed to charge-transfer transition between the H3 L ligand and the central Ln(III) ion .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed to explore the thermal stability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold> under a nitrogen atmosphere by heating the corresponding complexes from room temperature to at least 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (see Fig. S5 in the Supplementary material). The TGA curve exhibits that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features two stages of weight loss, the first weight loss of 5.36% between 274 and 324<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (peaking at 303<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C), corresponding to the loss of one water molecule (calcd: 5.54%). Then, the sample remains largely unchanged until the decomposition occurs at the temperature of ca. 620<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Finally, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> starts to quickly decompose with one sharp step of weight loss (peaking at 731<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C). The final residue is not characterized because its weight loss does not stop until heating ends at 900<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The TGA curve for <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold> shows a first weight loss of 5.85% in the range of 130–174<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (peaking at 154<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C), corresponding to the loss of coordinated free water molecules (calcd: 5.91%). The residue keeps thermally stable from 157 to 428<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and then shows a continuous weight loss of 39.41% from 430 to 900<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (peaking at 447 and 593<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C), revealing the decomposition of the coordination framework.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed to explore the thermal stability of 1 and S1 under a nitrogen atmosphere by heating the corresponding complexes from room temperature to at least 800°C with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 (see Fig. S5 in the Supplementary material). The TGA curve exhibits that 1 features two stages of weight loss, the first weight loss of 5.36% between 274 and 324°C (peaking at 303°C), corresponding to the loss of one water molecule (calcd: 5.54%). Then, the sample remains largely unchanged until the decomposition occurs at the temperature of ca. 620°C. Finally, complex 1 starts to quickly decompose with one sharp step of weight loss (peaking at 731°C). The final residue is not characterized because its weight loss does not stop until heating ends at 900°C. The TGA curve for S1 shows a first weight loss of 5.85% in the range of 130-174°C (peaking at 154°C), corresponding to the loss of coordinated free water molecules (calcd: 5.91%). The residue keeps thermally stable from 157 to 428°C, and then shows a continuous weight loss of 39.41% from 430 to 900°C (peaking at 447 and 593°C), revealing the decomposition of the coordination framework.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">In summary, two new lanthanide coordination polymers have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions by employing 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>) ligand, which exhibited (6,6)-connected 3D <ce:bold>nia</ce:bold> net with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">9</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and (3,6)-connected 2D (3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.4)(3<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.5<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>.7) net (<ce:bold>S1</ce:bold>), respectively. Especially, the La(III) complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> provides the first example of lanthanide architecture which the hydroxyl group of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> involving in the coordination. The present finding promotes us to make a further systemic study on the coordination chemistry of 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, which may enrich the design and synthesis of crystalline materials based on such versatile multidentate building blocks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, two new lanthanide coordination polymers have been prepared under hydrothermal conditions by employing 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (H3 L) ligand, which exhibited (6,6)-connected 3D nia net with Point (Schläfli) symbol of (412.63)(49.66) (1) and (3,6)-connected 2D (32.4)(34.43.52.65.7) net (S1), respectively. Especially, the La(III) complex 1 provides the first example of lanthanide architecture which the hydroxyl group of H3 L involving in the coordination. The present finding promotes us to make a further systemic study on the coordination chemistry of 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, which may enrich the design and synthesis of crystalline materials based on such versatile multidentate building blocks.

elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 1 and S1. A mixture of La(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.087 g), H3 L (0.3 mmol, 0.055 g), NaOH (0.3 mmol, 0.012 g), and water (10 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 3 days, and then cooled to room temperature. Colorless block crystals of 1 were obtained in yield ca. 40%. Anal. calcd for C8H5LaO6: C, 28.60; H, 1.50%. Found: C, 28.56; H, 1.55%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3587 (vs), 3262 (w), 3177 (w), 2361 (m), 1626 (w), 1589 (w), 1547 (s), 1430 (s), 1372 (s), 1311 (m), 1273 (s), 1116 (m), 1005 (m), 981 (s), 900 (w), 816 (m), 809 (w), 786 (vs), 727 (vs), 586 (s), 516 (m), 446 (s), 412 (s). Complex S1 was obtained by the similar procedure as used for 1 except the lanthanide salt was replaced by Ho(NO3) 3⋅6H2O (0.2 mmol, 0.092 g). After cooling to room temperature, suitable crystals of S1 were obtained in yield 40%. Anal. calcd for C24H18Ho2O18: C, 31.19; H, 1.96%. Found: C, 31.23; H, 1.92%. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3384 (br), 2976 (w), 2362 (w), 1630 (w), 1572 (m), 1537 (m), 1484 (w), 14589 (m), 1396 (s), 1308 (w), 1269 (s), 1224 (m), 1181 (m), 1130 (m), 1089 (w), 1048 (s), 1003 (s), 980 (s), 943 (w), 886 (m), 782 (s), 720 (s), 671 (w), 579 (w).

After cooling to room temperature, suitable crystals of S1 were obtained in yield 40%. Anal. calcd for C24H18Ho2O18: C, 31.19; H, 1.96%. Found: C, 31.23; H, 1.92%. <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand and the central Ln(III) ion .</ce:para><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed to explore the thermal stability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>S1</ce:bold> under a nitrogen atmosphere by heating the corresponding complexes from room temperature to at least 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (see Fig. S5 in the Supplementary material). cln_elements.clean_text:
In addition, the solid-state photoluminescent properties of 1 and S1 were investigated at room temperature, as shown in Fig. S4 in the Supplementary material. The luminescence emission bands with the peak maxima (λmax) were observed at 371nm (λex =341nm) for 1 and 350nm (λex =280nm) for S1, respectively. To further analyze the nature of these emission bands, the photoluminescent properties of the free H3 L have also been investigated under the same experimental conditions. The emission band for free H3 L ligand is attributable to the π*→n transitions. The fluorescent behaviors of 1 and S1 are very similar to that observed for the free H3 L ligand (see Fig. S4 in the Supplementary material), which displays the maximal emission at 364nm upon excitation at 345nm. Moreover, the emission mechanism for 1 and S1 can be properly ascribed to charge-transfer transition between the H3 L ligand and the central Ln(III) ion .

Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed to explore the thermal stability of 1 and S1 under a nitrogen atmosphere by heating the corresponding complexes from room temperature to at least 800°C with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 (see Fig. S5 in the Supplementary material). The TGA curve exhibits that 1 features two stages of weight loss, the first weight loss of 5.36% between 274 and 324°C (peaking at 303°C), corresponding to the loss of one water molecule (calcd: 5.54%). Then, the sample remains largely unchanged until the decomposition occurs at the temperature of ca. 620°C. Finally, complex 1 starts to quickly decompose with one sharp step of weight loss (peaking at 731°C). The final residue is not characterized because its weight loss does not stop until heating ends at 900°C. The TGA curve for S1 shows a first weight loss of 5.85% in the range of 130-174°C (peaking at 154°C), corresponding to the loss of coordinated free water molecules (calcd: 5.91%). The residue keeps thermally stable from 157 to 428°C, and then shows a continuous weight loss of 39.41% from 430 to 900°C (peaking at 447 and 593°C), revealing the decomposition of the coordination framework.

The data were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD area-detector diffractometer at 294(2) K with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω scan mode. The structure was solved by direct method using SHELXS-97 and all non-hydrogen atoms were subjected to anisotropic refinement by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. Crystal data for 1, C8H5LaO6, M = 336.03, Monoclinic, space group P21/c, a = 9.9715(5) Å, b = 11.7086(6) Å, c = 7.3056(3) Å, β = 91.439(4)º, V = 852.68(7) Å3, Z = 4, D  c  = 2.618 Mgּm-3, μ (Mo-Ka) = 5.015 mm-1, F(000) = 632, T = 294(2) K, R int = 0.0264, final R 1 = 0.0245, wR 2 = 0.0505 [for selected data with I > 2σ(I)], GOF = 1.129 for all data. Crystal data for S1, C24H18Ho2O18, M = 924.24, Monoclinic, space group P21/c, a = 10.7636(11) Å, b = 14.3485(13) Å, c = 17.528(2) Å, β = 102.116(11)º, V =2646.7(5) Å3, Z = 4, D  c  = 2.319 Mgּm-3, μ (Mo-Ka) = 6.026 mm-1, F(000) = 1760, T = 294(2) K, R int = 0.0565, final R 1 = 0.0578, wR 2 = 0.1628 [for selected data with I > 2σ(I)], GOF = 1.069 for all data.
